subject: history
title: Tribal & Peasant Movements (19th-20th Century)
description: Uprisings against British exploitation; land revenue; forest laws

rows.causes:
Leaders: Sidhu, Kanhu (brothers)

Causes:
• Oppression by zamindars, moneylenders
• Land alienation
• Heavy taxation
• Forest rights denied
rows.outcome:
Suppressed brutally (10,000+ killed)

Significance: Largest tribal uprising before 1857; showed tribal resistance to colonial exploitation

Key Exam Points: Sidhu-Kanhu; 1855-56; Pre-1857

rows.causes:
Causes:
• Forced indigo cultivation (Tinkathia system)
• Below-market prices
• Beatings, torture by planters
• Debt bondage

Inspired: Dinabandhu Mitra's play 'Nil Darpan' (1860)
rows.outcome:
Limited success: Some relief; Indigo Commission (1860)

Later: Gandhi's Champaran Satyagraha (1917) continued fight

Key Exam Points: Tinkathia system; Nil Darpan play; Led to Champaran

rows.causes:
Causes:
• Zamindars' illegal rent increases
• Oppression
• Peasants formed Agrarian League
rows.outcome:
Impact: Tenant Protection Act; showed peasants could organize

Key Exam Points: Bengal; against zamindars; 1873

rows.causes:
Causes:
• Moneylenders' exploitation
• Debt burden
• Famine (1876-77)
• Peasants burned debt bonds
rows.outcome:
Result: Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act (1879) - limited moneylender powers

Key Exam Points: 1875; Maharashtra; anti-moneylender; Debt Relief Act

rows.causes:
Context: During Khilafat-NCM (1920-21)

Causes:
• Landlord (mostly Hindu) oppression
• Muslim tenants (Moplahs) exploited
• Religious + agrarian grievances mixed
rows.outcome:
Turned violent: Hindu-Muslim riots; 10,000+ killed; British suppressed brutally

Impact: Damaged Hindu-Muslim unity; Congress embarrassed

Key Exam Points: 1921; Kerala; religious+agrarian; hurt Hindu-Muslim unity

rows.causes:
Leader: Vallabhbhai Patel

Cause: 22% tax increase despite crop failure

Method: Gandhian no-tax campaign
rows.outcome:
Success: Tax reduced; Patel earned title 'Sardar'

Significance: Successful peasant satyagraha; template for future

Key Exam Points: 1928; Patel = 'Sardar'; No-tax; Success

rows.causes:
Demand: Sharecroppers' share from 1/2 to 2/3 (Tebhaga = 2/3)

Led by: Kisan Sabha; Communist influence
rows.outcome:
Suppressed; Some reforms later

Key Exam Points: 1946; Bengal; 2/3 share demand; Communist-led

rows.causes:
Against: Nizam & landlords' exploitation

Led by: Communist Party

Demand: Land to tillers
rows.outcome:
Armed struggle; Suppressed after police action (1948)

Key Exam Points: 1946-51; Communist-led; Hyderabad; Land redistribution

characteristics.common:
• Against British/zamindars/moneylenders
• Land rights, forest rights, taxation
• Often localized; limited coordination
• Brutally suppressed
• Some influenced by national movement (Gandhian methods)
characteristics.significance: Showed rural discontent; British economicexploitation affected everyone; Peasants/tribals active in freedom struggle

examTips.critical: Santhal (1855) - Sidhu-Kanhu; Indigo (1859) - Nil Darpan → Champaran (1917); Moplah (1921) - hurt unity; Bardoli (1928) - Patel = 'Sardar'
